results.title: An Introduction to motor cycling
results.creator_credit: Tony Hansen, Peter Johnson, Timothy Read and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Motorcycle safety”.
Inexperience, unpreparedness, and a powerful machine, are al1 factors which cause motor cycle accidents, and contribute to an awful and unnecessary waste. Points out the different types of motor cycles appropriate to different individuals, purposes and situations, as well as explaining how a motor cycle works.

results.title: An Introduction to materials: the manufacture of silicon solar cells
results.creator_credit: Barrie Whatley, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: First of two films on solar cells. Includes an experiment to determine which wave lengths of light are absorbed by silicon. Describes the generation of electron-hole pairs and illustrates the process of drift, diffusion and recombination.

results.title: An Introduction to feedback
results.creator_credit: Ray Eames, Charles Eames and IBM
results.brief_description: A simple presentation of the feedback idea, its growing importance in technology and the use of the data processor for continuous measurement, evaluation and correction in, for example, the petroleum industry and traffic control. Like most of the films by Ray and Charles Eames, this is not traditional in content or approach. Music by Elmer Bernstein.

results.title: An introduction to color mixing using the Liquitex Color Map
results.creator_credit: Binney and Smith, Art Products Division
results.brief_description: Russell Woody shows how to mix colour from a visual, rather than a theoretical perspective. Addresses how to select alternate colours to save money, how to correct failed colour mixes with minimal mixing, how to compare colours for opacity, outstanding coverage and transparency and glazes or washes. Provides an understanding of basic colour terms, how one colour can have several names, how words can distort colour vision and how to alleviate the problem.

results.title: An Introduction to Aussie sports
results.creator_credit: Stephen Skok and Australian Sports Commission
results.brief_description: Max Walker, ex-Australian cricketer, introduces an educational program designed to encourage greater on-going participation in sports by children. Outlines modified team games such as Softcrosse, modified hockey, mini-soccer and T-Ball. Describes the awards scheme for four Aussie Sports and makes reference to the resource manual accompanying the sports.

results.title: An Interview with Wing Commander Peter Isaacson : Chairman of the Shrine of Remembrance Trustees (1983-2000)
results.creator_credit: Peter Isaacson and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: After returning from World War II, having served in the RAAF as a Pathfinder, Peter Isaacson was appointed a Shrine of Remembrance Trustee. He discusses his time at the Shrine, as Chairman of the Shrine of Remembrance Trustees and the role of the Shrine in helping Australians remember as well as teaching those who don’t remember the history of Australia at war.

results.title: An Interview with Wes Bailey
results.brief_description: With a vibrant sense of humour, Wes Bailey recounts his various postings as a signaller during World War II. Long hot days of being eaten alive by mozzies as well as the expected pleasures of fruit and vegetables have nothing on the most significant posting of Bailey’s career, as husband to fellow signaller Phil Bailey.

results.title: An Interview with Warwick N. Johanson
results.brief_description: After joining the Navy when he turned 17, one of the first lessons Warwick Johanson learnt was that if anything moved, you saluted it, if it stood still, you polished it. His home for over four years was aboard the flagship, the HMAS Australia, often a target for the formidable Japanese Kamakaze. Warwick also reflects on World War II and what it was like in Australia, when the country was actually in peril, almost unimaginable in this day and age.

results.title: An Interview with Valda Maskell and Alf
results.creator_credit: Alfred Maskell, Valda Maskell and ACMI
results.brief_description: Valda Maskell, with the assistance of her husband Alfred, gives a touching account of how their love for each other survived World War 2. Valda met Alfred in Bendigo and they managed to get engaged just before Alfred was despatched to Malaya to fight the Japanese. The story is mostly told from Valda’s perspective, how she joined the RAAF and worked there as a cook and how she spent three years working there, all the while knowing nothing of Alfred’s fate. On his return, Valda promptly went AWOL, married Alfred and shares with us the ups and downs of her life with a returned soldier, who was also a prisoner of war.

On his return, Valda promptly went AWOL, married Alfred and shares with us the ups and downs of her life with a returned soldier, who was also a prisoner of war.

results.title: An Interview with Susan George
results.creator_credit: Mark Stiles, Mary Leggett and Freedom From Hunger
results.brief_description: Susan George, food economist and author of “How the other half dies” talks about food distribution in the world, reasons for starvation amongst third world peoples and the influence of the western world upon third world hunger problems.
